```if filter[service] == X
and group_by[service] == *

then group_by[service] = X```

text:
so if someone does this:
`?filter[service]=AmazonS3&filter[service]=AmazonEC2&group_by[service]=*`

then what they actually want is this:
`?group_by[service]=AmazonS3&group_by[service]=AmazonEC2`
right?

elements.text: then what they actually want is this:

and if someone does this:
`?filter[X]=Y1&filter[Z]=K1&filter[Z]=K2&group_by[X]=*&group_by[Z]=*`
then what they want is this:
`group_by[X]=Y1&group_by[Z]=K1, K2`
?

elements.text: then what they want is this:

`?filter[X]=Y1&filter[Z]=K1&filter[Z]=K2&group_by[X]=*`

text: i removed the group_by[Z]=*
Yeah, that should be supported. `?group_by[X]=Y1&filter[Z]=K1,K2`

text: yes
group by isn’t respecting filters.
question: is ?filter[resolution]=monthly only counting the last 10 days?

elements.text: question: is ?filter[resolution]=monthly only counting the last 10 days?

text: <https://github.com/project-koku/koku/blob/master/koku/api/report/serializers.py#L200> is part of the answer to what time scope unit/value/resolutions are allowed.

elements.text: is part of the answer to what time scope unit/value/resolutions are allowed.

text: -1 == current month, -2 == last month, -10 == last 10 days.

elements.text: -1 == current month, -2 == last month, -10 == last 10 days.

text: Keep in mind I’m not defending or indicting this answer, just what those translate to.

elements.text: Keep in mind I’m not defending or indicting this answer, just what those translate to.

text: resolution monthly just aggregates the results into a single field for the month, instead of a different result for each day.

elements.text: resolution monthly just aggregates the results into a single field for the month, instead of a different result for each day.

text: So if you use -1 or -2 and resolultion monthly than you get a full month

elements.text: So if you use -1 or -2 and resolultion monthly than you get a full month

`?group_by[service]=AmazonS3&filter[service]=AmazonEC2`
